snippet: After 2009’s disputed presidential election, the Iranian authorities — who have long touted voter turnout as an index of their government’s democratic legitimacy — must lure people back to the polls.
abstract: Iranian authorities are trying to lure people back to the polls after 2009's disputed presidential election and before the imminent parliamentary elections; top officials, including supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, have been crisscrossing the country to issue stern warnings against a vast Western conspiracy, driven by panic, to undermine the vote; leaders of the opposition movement have been placed under house arrest or jailed, along with hundreds of their leading supporters.
lead_paragraph: After 2009’s disputed presidential election, the Iranian authorities — who have long touted voter turnout as an index of their government’s democratic legitimacy — must lure people back to the polls.

headline.seo: Iran Invokes the West to Scare Up Voters
headline.main: Iran Invokes the West to Motivate Voters
headline.print_headline: Iran Invokes the West to Motivate Voters
